comments:
MATH508 covers real analysis, the graduate-level version of MATH360. This course teaches students how to read and construct rigorous formal proofs. The elements of elementary calculus are revisited from a theoretical perspective. Topics covered include the construction of the real number, the topology of the real line, and the foundations of single-variable calculus; notions of convergence for sequences of functions; and basic approximation theorems for continuous functions and rigorous treatment of elementary transcendental functions. This is the first course in the two-semester analysis sequence.

Most students did not enjoy MATH508, saying that it was an “awful” and “frustrating” course. Students complained that it did not match the course description. One student commented, “This was supposed to be a Real Analysis course, and the phrase ‘Real Analysis’ didn't even come up until the next-to-last week of class.” Others felt the pace of the class was too slow. On the other hand, one reviewer said the class was great.

Many students expressed disappointment with Professor Kadison. They felt he taught too slowly, overlooked the more advanced background of the students enrolled, and didn’t challenged them enough. They also felt his “informal” lecture style was inappropriate for the “rigor” of the course content, adding that lectures were often filled with anecdotes irrelevant to the course material. In addition, some students took offense at Professor Kadison’s attitude when he “became very smug” and told certain students not to take the next course in the sequence. However, a few students appreciated Professor Kadison’s approach, with one student commenting that “Professor Kadison has taught me how to think like a good mathematician.”

MATH508 is a course taken almost exclusively by mathematics majors. MATH240/241 is a prerequisite, and completion of a freshman seminar (MATH202/203) is recommended. One student complained, “Exams were based on rote regurgitation of definitions in the notes, or proofs already demonstrated in class; grading on the exam was arbitrary. The course grading rubric was about as arbitrary, with 25% attendance and 25% ‘decorum’”. The same student compared the difficulty of the class to a 100- or 200- level class. Another reviewer grumbled that “The final grade was 50% participation,” while “the rest of the grade was composed of three homework assignments and one midterm.” Yet another student wrote, “Professor Kadison repeatedly changed the grading structure for the course, which ultimately ruined a number of students grades at the end of the semester.”
